procedures.name: rotate-reverse technique, modification of tomita spondylectomy
procedures.description: en bloc resection with posterior approach
procedures.indications:
enneking stage 3 aggresive benign tumors 
1a,1b low grade and 2a,2b high grade primary malign bone tumors
procedures.contraindications: metasthases and lokal, active tumors, patitent multiple comorbidities

procedures.name: Craniotomy for Tumor Resection
procedures.description: Surgical procedure to remove brain tumors through a bone flap opening in the skull.
procedures.indications: Primary brain tumors (gliomas, meningiomas), metastatic brain tumors, accessible lesions causing mass effect or neurological deficits
procedures.contraindications: Diffuse infiltrative tumors, poor surgical candidacy, lesions in eloquent areas without mapping capability

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Position patient based on tumor location. Supine for frontal/temporal, lateral for parietal, prone/sitting for posterior fossa. Secure head in Mayfield pins.
steps.tips: Ensure adequate venous drainage by avoiding excessive neck flexion
steps.warnings: Check pin sites for pressure points

steps.title: Skin Incision & Flap
steps.description: Plan incision to allow adequate exposure. Create scalp flap with preservation of vascular pedicle.
steps.tips: Use neuronavigation for trajectory planning
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to superficial temporal artery

steps.title: Craniotomy
steps.description: Create burr holes at planned locations. Use craniotome to connect burr holes. Elevate bone flap carefully.
steps.tips: Keep bone flap moist in saline-soaked gauze
steps.warnings: Watch for dural adhesions to inner table

steps.title: Dural Opening
steps.description: Open dura in cruciate or curvilinear fashion. Tack up dural edges to prevent epidural bleeding.
steps.tips: Leave dural cuff for watertight closure
steps.warnings: Identify and protect cortical veins

steps.title: Tumor Resection
steps.description: Identify tumor margins using navigation, ultrasound, and/or fluorescence. Debulk tumor internally then dissect margins.
steps.tips: Use ultrasonic aspirator for firm tumors
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to eloquent cortex and major vessels

steps.title: Hemostasis & Closure
steps.description: Achieve meticulous hemostasis. Close dura watertight. Replace bone flap and secure with plates/screws. Close in layers.
steps.tips: Consider dural substitute if primary closure not possible
steps.warnings: Ensure no tension on brain surface before closing dura

procedures.name: Lumbar Microdiscectomy
procedures.description: Minimally invasive removal of herniated disc material compressing neural structures.
procedures.indications: Lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy, failed conservative treatment (6+ weeks), progressive neurological deficit, cauda equina syndrome
procedures.contraindications: Spinal instability, significant central stenosis, infection at surgical site

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Position prone on Wilson frame or Jackson table. Flex hips and knees to open interlaminar space. Apply padding to pressure points.
steps.tips: Ensure abdomen is free to reduce epidural venous pressure
steps.warnings: Avoid pressure on eyes and genitalia

steps.title: Localization
steps.description: Use fluoroscopy to confirm correct level. Mark incision site (typically 1-2 cm from midline on affected side).
steps.tips: Count from sacrum upward for accurate localization
steps.warnings: Wrong level surgery is a preventable complication

steps.title: Incision & Exposure
steps.description: Make 2-3 cm paramedian incision. Dissect through fascia. Use tubular retractor or self-retaining retractor to expose lamina.
steps.tips: Muscle-splitting approach reduces postoperative pain
steps.warnings: Stay lateral to spinous process

steps.title: Laminotomy
steps.description: Remove inferior portion of superior lamina and ligamentum flavum using Kerrison rongeurs. Create adequate window to visualize nerve root.
steps.tips: Use high-speed drill for calcified ligamentum
steps.warnings: Protect underlying dura during bone removal

steps.title: Nerve Root Retraction
steps.description: Identify and gently retract traversing nerve root medially. Identify disc herniation.
steps.tips: Use nerve root retractor with gentle pressure only
steps.warnings: Excessive retraction causes postoperative dysesthesia

steps.title: Discectomy
steps.description: Incise posterior annulus. Remove herniated disc fragment with pituitary rongeurs. Explore foramen for residual fragments.
steps.tips: Use angled curettes to check under endplates
steps.warnings: Avoid aggressive disc space curettage - increases recurrence

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Achieve hemostasis with bipolar and hemostatic agents. Close fascia and skin in layers.
steps.tips: Fascia closure is critical to prevent CSF leak if dural tear occurred
steps.warnings: Document any incidental durotomy

procedures.name: Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) Shunt Placement
procedures.description: Surgical diversion of cerebrospinal fluid from the lateral ventricle to the peritoneal cavity for treatment of hydrocephalus.
procedures.indications: Communicating hydrocephalus, obstructive hydrocephalus, normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), pseudotumor cerebri refractory to medical management
procedures.contraindications: Active CNS or abdominal infection, peritoneal adhesions/malignancy, coagulopathy

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Review imaging for ventricle size and optimal entry point. Typically use Kocher point (frontal) or occipital approach.
steps.tips: Kocher point: 11cm posterior to nasion, 3cm lateral to midline, anterior to coronal suture
steps.warnings: Avoid motor strip and major vessels

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with head turned to contralateral side. Prep from scalp to lower abdomen. Roll under ipsilateral shoulder.
steps.tips: Ensure head and abdomen in same surgical field
steps.warnings: Secure head position to prevent movement

steps.title: Ventricular Catheter Placement
steps.description: Make burr hole at planned entry point. Open dura with cruciate incision. Insert ventricular catheter perpendicular to skull surface aiming at medial canthus of ipsilateral eye.
steps.tips: Target depth is typically 5-7cm from outer table
steps.warnings: Multiple passes increase hemorrhage risk

steps.title: Subcutaneous Tunneling
steps.description: Create pocket for valve behind ear. Use tunneling device to create subcutaneous path from cranial incision to abdominal incision.
steps.tips: Keep tunneler superficial to fascia
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to jugular vein in neck

steps.title: Abdominal Catheter Placement
steps.description: Make periumbilical or subcostal incision. Open peritoneum under direct vision. Insert distal catheter 20-25cm into peritoneal cavity.
steps.tips: Laparoscopic assistance useful in revision cases
steps.warnings: Ensure catheter tip is free and not kinked

steps.title: System Assembly & Testing
steps.description: Connect ventricular catheter to valve and distal tubing. Confirm CSF flow. Set programmable valve if applicable.
steps.tips: Document valve setting and type
steps.warnings: Avoid air in system

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Close peritoneum, fascia, and skin at abdominal site. Close scalp in layers over valve.
steps.tips: Ensure valve is palpable but not under tension
steps.warnings: Meticulous closure prevents CSF leak and infection

procedures.name: Aneurysm Clipping
procedures.description: Microsurgical obliteration of intracranial aneurysm using permanent clip to exclude it from circulation.
procedures.indications: Ruptured intracranial aneurysm, unruptured aneurysm >7mm or symptomatic, aneurysm with unfavorable morphology for coiling
procedures.contraindications: Severe vasospasm, poor neurological grade (Hunt-Hess V with poor prognosis), fusiform/dissecting aneurysms

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Review CT/CTA/DSA for aneurysm location, morphology, neck width, and relationship to parent/branch vessels. Plan craniotomy approach.
steps.tips: 3D reconstructions help understand complex anatomy
steps.warnings: Identify perforating vessels near aneurysm dome

steps.title: Craniotomy
steps.description: Pterional craniotomy for most anterior circulation aneurysms. Remove sphenoid wing flush with middle fossa floor for optimal visualization.
steps.tips: Extensive bone removal allows brain relaxation and reduces retraction
steps.warnings: Protect optic nerve with minimal sphenoid drilling

steps.title: CSF Drainage & Brain Relaxation
steps.description: Open Sylvian fissure and cisterns to release CSF. Consider lumbar drain for tight brain.
steps.tips: Mannitol and hyperventilation as adjuncts
steps.warnings: Avoid premature aneurysm exposure with tight brain

steps.title: Proximal Control
steps.description: Identify and prepare internal carotid artery for temporary clipping if needed. Expose proximal parent vessel.
steps.tips: Have temporary clips ready before dissecting aneurysm
steps.warnings: Know location of M1, A1 for emergency control

steps.title: Aneurysm Dissection
steps.description: Carefully dissect aneurysm neck under high magnification. Identify all branches and perforators. Clear dome last.
steps.tips: Sharp dissection reduces rupture risk
steps.warnings: Dome is most fragile - avoid manipulation until neck is ready

steps.title: Clip Application
steps.description: Select appropriate clip type and size. Apply clip across neck perpendicular to parent vessel. Confirm complete obliteration.
steps.tips: Clip should be parallel to parent vessel axis
steps.warnings: Avoid stenosis of parent vessel or branch occlusion

steps.title: Verification & Closure
steps.description: Perform ICG angiography or micro-Doppler to confirm parent vessel patency. Inspect for residual filling. Standard craniotomy closure.
steps.tips: Intraoperative angiography is gold standard
steps.warnings: Do not leave residual neck - rebleeding risk

procedures.name: Transsphenoidal Pituitary Adenoma Resection
procedures.description: Endoscopic or microscopic approach through the sphenoid sinus for removal of pituitary tumors.
procedures.indications: Pituitary macroadenoma with visual compromise, hormone-secreting adenoma, pituitary apoplexy
procedures.contraindications: Sphenoid sinus infection, uncontrolled coagulopathy, significant lateral cavernous sinus extension (relative)

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with head in neutral position or slight extension. Apply Mayfield head holder or horseshoe. Position neuronavigation array.
steps.tips: Slight head elevation reduces venous pressure
steps.warnings: Confirm registration accuracy before proceeding

steps.title: Nasal Phase
steps.description: Perform wide sphenoidotomy using endoscopic or sublabial microscopic approach. Remove middle turbinate if needed for exposure.
steps.tips: Avoid septal perforations by careful submucosal dissection
steps.warnings: Identify sphenoid ostium and rostrum landmarks

steps.title: Sphenoid Phase
steps.description: Open anterior sphenoid wall widely. Identify sellar floor, carotid prominences, optic nerve impressions, and clival recess.
steps.tips: Use navigation to confirm midline
steps.warnings: Do not stray lateral to carotid prominences

steps.title: Sellar Phase
steps.description: Remove sellar floor bone to expose dura. Open sellar dura in cruciate fashion after confirming normal position.
steps.tips: Venous bleeding indicates cavernous sinus entry
steps.warnings: Watch for ectatic or dehiscent carotid artery

steps.title: Tumor Removal
steps.description: Remove tumor using ring curettes and suction. Systematic exploration of sellar cavity - inferior, lateral, superior compartments.
steps.tips: Angled endoscopes visualize suprasellar extension
steps.warnings: Preserve normal pituitary gland posteriorly and superiorly

steps.title: CSF Leak Management
steps.description: Perform Valsalva maneuver to check for CSF leak. If present, repair with fat graft, fascia lata, and/or nasoseptal flap.
steps.tips: Multilayer closure for high-flow leaks
steps.warnings: Unrepaired leak leads to meningitis

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Pack sphenoid sinus with fat or absorbable material. Place nasal splints or packing as needed. Remove lumbar drain if placed.
steps.tips: Minimize nasal packing to reduce patient discomfort
steps.warnings: Instruct patient on CSF leak precautions postoperatively

procedures.name: Anterior Cervical Discectomy and Fusion (ACDF)
procedures.description: Anterior approach to remove cervical disc and decompress neural elements with interbody fusion.
procedures.indications: Cervical radiculopathy from disc herniation, cervical myelopathy from disc or osteophyte, degenerative disc disease with instability
procedures.contraindications: Active infection, severe osteoporosis (relative), previous anterior neck surgery with scarring (relative)

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with neck in neutral position. Place shoulder roll. Slight extension for exposure. Apply Gardner-Wells tongs or tape for traction.
steps.tips: Avoid hyperextension in myelopathic patients
steps.warnings: Confirm no instability on flexion-extension X-rays

steps.title: Approach
steps.description: Make transverse skin incision at planned level (use landmarks: C3-4 = hyoid, C4-5 = thyroid, C5-6 = cricoid). Dissect along medial border of SCM.
steps.tips: Left-sided approach avoids recurrent laryngeal nerve variation
steps.warnings: Protect carotid sheath laterally, esophagus/trachea medially

steps.title: Level Identification
steps.description: Confirm level with lateral fluoroscopy using spinal needle in disc space. Mark adjacent levels if multi-level.
steps.tips: Place marker at most caudal level and count up
steps.warnings: Wrong level surgery - always confirm radiographically

steps.title: Disc Removal
steps.description: Place Caspar or similar distraction pins. Remove anterior annulus and disc with pituitary rongeurs and curettes. Clear to posterior longitudinal ligament.
steps.tips: Use operating microscope or loupe magnification
steps.warnings: Stay midline - lateral is vertebral artery

steps.title: Decompression
steps.description: Remove posterior osteophytes with high-speed drill and Kerrison rongeurs. Decompress nerve roots bilaterally. Remove PLL if compressive.
steps.tips: Identify uncovertebral joints as lateral limits
steps.warnings: Thin posterior osteophytes before removing to protect cord

steps.title: Fusion
steps.description: Measure interbody space. Insert appropriately sized PEEK or allograft cage packed with bone graft or substitute. Confirm position with fluoroscopy.
steps.tips: Cage should be 1-2mm proud of vertebral bodies
steps.warnings: Oversized cage causes endplate fracture

steps.title: Plating & Closure
steps.description: Apply anterior cervical plate with variable-angle screws. Confirm hardware position. Close platysma, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.
steps.tips: Bicortical screw purchase improves stability
steps.warnings: Screws should not violate posterior cortex or disc space

procedures.name: Decompressive Craniectomy
procedures.description: Emergency removal of large skull segment to allow brain swelling and reduce intracranial pressure.
procedures.indications: Malignant MCA infarction, severe TBI with refractory ICP elevation, large hemorrhagic stroke with mass effect
procedures.contraindications: GCS 3 with bilateral fixed dilated pupils (relative), extensive bilateral damage, devastating primary injury with no chance of meaningful recovery

steps.title: Preoperative Assessment
steps.description: Review CT for midline shift, cisternal effacement, herniation. Assess neurological status. Discuss prognosis with family.
steps.tips: Document pre-op neuro exam clearly
steps.warnings: This is salvage surgery - outcomes vary widely

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with head turned or lateral position. Elevate head of bed 30 degrees. Apply Mayfield pins avoiding area of decompression.
steps.tips: Ensure adequate surgical field - entire hemicranium exposed
steps.warnings: Avoid jugular compression

steps.title: Skin Incision
steps.description: Large question-mark or trauma flap incision. Must extend to floor of middle fossa and across midline. Preserve superficial temporal artery if possible.
steps.tips: Plan for future cranioplasty
steps.warnings: Inadequate exposure leads to inadequate decompression

steps.title: Craniectomy
steps.description: Create multiple burr holes. Perform large craniectomy (minimum 12cm AP x 15cm vertical). Remove bone to middle fossa floor and within 2cm of midline.
steps.tips: Larger is better for decompression
steps.warnings: Small craniectomy causes brain fungation and herniation through defect

steps.title: Durotomy
steps.description: Open dura widely in stellate or cruciate fashion. Allow brain to expand. Do not attempt duraplasty if brain is very swollen.
steps.tips: Score dura in multiple places if needed
steps.warnings: Venous bleeding from sagittal sinus - stay 2cm from midline

steps.title: Duraplasty
steps.description: If brain is not excessively swollen, perform expansion duraplasty with pericranium, dural substitute, or fascial graft.
steps.tips: Watertight closure not essential in emergency setting
steps.warnings: Do not compress brain with tight duraplasty

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Close galea and skin loosely. Store bone flap in subcutaneous abdominal pocket or bone bank (-80°C). Plan cranioplasty for 6-12 weeks later.
steps.tips: Abdominal storage has higher bone viability
steps.warnings: Document bone storage location clearly

procedures.name: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma) Resection
procedures.description: Microsurgical removal of benign tumor arising from vestibular nerve, typically via retrosigmoid or translabyrinthine approach.
procedures.indications: Growing tumor, tumor >2.5cm, symptomatic with hearing loss/tinnitus/imbalance, brainstem compression
procedures.contraindications: Elderly with small stable tumor, only hearing ear (relative), significant medical comorbidities

steps.title: Approach Selection
steps.description: Choose based on tumor size and hearing status: Retrosigmoid (hearing preservation attempt), Translabyrinthine (no serviceable hearing, excellent facial nerve exposure), Middle fossa (small intracanalicular, hearing preservation).
steps.tips: Preoperative audiometry essential for decision-making
steps.warnings: Discuss realistic expectations for hearing and facial nerve outcomes

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Lateral position (retrosigmoid/translabyrinthine) or supine with head turned (middle fossa). Monitor facial nerve EMG. Consider ABR monitoring.
steps.tips: Test facial nerve monitoring before incision
steps.warnings: Ensure all team members know stimulation thresholds

steps.title: Craniotomy/Mastoidectomy
steps.description: Retrosigmoid: posterior fossa craniotomy behind sigmoid sinus. Translabyrinthine: complete mastoidectomy with labyrinthectomy exposing IAC.
steps.tips: Identify sigmoid sinus and jugular bulb early
steps.warnings: Injury to sigmoid/jugular causes major hemorrhage

steps.title: Dural Opening & Cistern Access
steps.description: Open dura, release CSF from cisterna magna for brain relaxation. Identify tumor in CPA.
steps.tips: Gentle cerebellar retraction only
steps.warnings: PICA and AICA run near tumor - identify early

steps.title: Tumor Debulking
steps.description: Internally debulk tumor using ultrasonic aspirator or laser. Maintain capsule integrity. Identify facial nerve plane early.
steps.tips: Facial nerve usually anterior-inferior on tumor surface
steps.warnings: Stimulate frequently to locate facial nerve

steps.title: Capsule Dissection
steps.description: Carefully separate tumor capsule from facial nerve, cochlear nerve (if preserving), and brainstem. Sharp dissection preferred.
steps.tips: Slow dissection near facial nerve with continuous monitoring
steps.warnings: Do not pull on tumor - stretches facial nerve

steps.title: IAC Drilling
steps.description: Drill posterior wall of internal auditory canal to remove intracanalicular tumor. Identify lateral end of tumor.
steps.tips: Continuous irrigation prevents thermal injury
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to labyrinth if hearing preservation planned

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Achieve hemostasis. Pack mastoid with fat (translabyrinthine). Close dura watertight. Consider lumbar drain for high-risk CSF leak.
steps.tips: Fat obliteration reduces CSF leak risk
steps.warnings: CSF leak most common complication - meticulous closure essential

procedures.name: Chronic Subdural Hematoma Evacuation
procedures.description: Surgical drainage of chronic subdural blood collection through burr holes or craniotomy.
procedures.indications: Symptomatic chronic subdural hematoma, midline shift >5mm, neurological deterioration, hematoma thickness >10mm
procedures.contraindications: Asymptomatic small hematoma, coagulopathy (correct first), patient on anticoagulation (reverse if possible)

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Review CT for hematoma location, thickness, presence of membranes/loculations, midline shift. Single vs bilateral. Check coagulation status.
steps.tips: Bilateral hematomas require bilateral procedures
steps.warnings: Hold anticoagulants and correct coagulopathy

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with head turned or in Mayfield if craniotomy planned. Prep widely to allow extension if needed.
steps.tips: Slight head elevation reduces venous pressure
steps.warnings: Mark correct side clearly

steps.title: Burr Hole Technique
steps.description: One or two burr holes over maximum thickness. Frontal burr hole near coronal suture, parietal burr hole behind coronal suture.
steps.tips: Two burr holes allow irrigation through and through
steps.warnings: Be cautious if hematoma is under pressure

steps.title: Hematoma Drainage
steps.description: Open dura carefully. Liquefied hematoma will drain spontaneously. Irrigate gently with warm saline until clear.
steps.tips: Patient coughing helps expel residual hematoma
steps.warnings: Aggressive irrigation can injure brain

steps.title: Subdural Drain Placement
steps.description: Place soft silicone drain into subdural space. Direct anteriorly and posteriorly. Connect to closed drainage system.
steps.tips: Drain for 24-48 hours reduces recurrence
steps.warnings: Avoid drain migration into brain parenchyma

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Close galea and skin. Tape drain securely. Bed rest with head of bed flat or slightly elevated for 24-48 hours.
steps.tips: Flat positioning allows brain re-expansion
steps.warnings: Early mobilization increases recurrence risk

steps.title: Postoperative Care
steps.description: Monitor neurological status. Check CT at 24-48 hours before drain removal. Hydration to allow brain re-expansion.
steps.tips: Gradual head elevation after drain removal
steps.warnings: Recurrence rate 10-20% - counsel patient

procedures.name: Posterior Lumbar Interbody Fusion (PLIF)
procedures.description: Posterior approach lumbar fusion with interbody cage placement and pedicle screw fixation.
procedures.indications: Degenerative disc disease with instability, spondylolisthesis, recurrent disc herniation, failed back surgery syndrome
procedures.contraindications: Active infection, severe osteoporosis, medical comorbidities precluding major surgery

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Prone on Jackson table or Wilson frame. Ensure abdomen is free. Apply padding to all pressure points. Prep for posterior approach.
steps.tips: Proper positioning reduces blood loss significantly
steps.warnings: Avoid direct pressure on eyes

steps.title: Exposure
steps.description: Midline incision over planned levels. Subperiosteal dissection to expose spinous processes, laminae, facets, and transverse processes.
steps.tips: Bovie cautery on bone surface reduces bleeding
steps.warnings: Stay in midline to minimize muscle injury

steps.title: Pedicle Screw Placement
steps.description: Identify pedicle entry points using anatomic landmarks. Use fluoroscopy and/or navigation. Create pilot hole, sound pedicle, tap, insert screw.
steps.tips: Freehand technique: 10-15° lateral angulation, follow pedicle axis
steps.warnings: Medial breach risks nerve root injury

steps.title: Decompression
steps.description: Perform laminectomy or laminotomy. Remove ligamentum flavum. Expose dura and nerve roots. Decompress laterally to foramina.
steps.tips: Preserve facet joints if not fusing that level
steps.warnings: Protect dura during bone removal

steps.title: Discectomy
steps.description: Retract thecal sac medially. Incise annulus. Perform thorough discectomy with curettes and pituitary rongeurs. Prepare endplates.
steps.tips: Cartilaginous endplate removal improves fusion rates
steps.warnings: Avoid penetrating anterior annulus - major vessels at risk

steps.title: Cage Insertion
steps.description: Size interbody space. Pack cages with bone graft. Insert bilateral PLIF cages. Confirm position and restore disc height.
steps.tips: Angle cage insertion to optimize position
steps.warnings: Oversized cage causes nerve root compression

steps.title: Rod Placement & Compression
steps.description: Contour rods to match lumbar lordosis. Insert rods and secure with set screws. Apply gentle compression across construct.
steps.tips: Check sagittal alignment before final tightening
steps.warnings: Excessive compression causes foraminal stenosis

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Copious irrigation. Hemostasis. Place drain if significant oozing. Close fascia, subcutaneous tissue, and skin in layers.
steps.tips: Meticulous fascial closure prevents CSF leak if dural injury occurred
steps.warnings: Document screw sizes and positions

procedures.name: Endoscopic Third Ventriculostomy (ETV)
procedures.description: Minimally invasive endoscopic procedure to create communication between third ventricle and prepontine cistern for obstructive hydrocephalus.
procedures.indications: Obstructive hydrocephalus, aqueductal stenosis, posterior fossa tumor with hydrocephalus, shunt infection requiring shunt removal
procedures.contraindications: Communicating hydrocephalus, prepontine scarring, severely abnormal anatomy, very small third ventricle

steps.title: Patient Selection
steps.description: Confirm obstructive hydrocephalus on MRI. Evaluate floor of third ventricle and prepontine cistern. Check for scarring or anatomic abnormalities.
steps.tips: ETV success score helps predict outcome
steps.warnings: Best results in older children/adults with aqueductal stenosis

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with head in Mayfield or horseshoe. Flex neck slightly. Prep for frontal burr hole.
steps.tips: Navigation helpful but not essential
steps.warnings: Ensure head position allows midline trajectory

steps.title: Burr Hole & Approach
steps.description: Frontal burr hole at Kocher point (3cm lateral to midline, 1cm anterior to coronal suture). Open dura. Coagulate and open pia.
steps.tips: Slightly more anterior and medial than VP shunt trajectory
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to sagittal sinus and cortical veins

steps.title: Ventricular Entry
steps.description: Advance endoscope perpendicular to skull surface toward ipsilateral medial canthus. Enter lateral ventricle. Identify foramen of Monro.
steps.tips: Irrigate continuously to maintain visualization
steps.warnings: Avoid septal vein and choroid plexus injury

steps.title: Third Ventricle Navigation
steps.description: Pass endoscope through foramen of Monro into third ventricle. Identify floor landmarks: mammillary bodies, infundibular recess, tuber cinereum.
steps.tips: Floor should be thin and translucent ideally
steps.warnings: Thick scarred floor reduces success and increases risk

steps.title: Fenestration
steps.description: Identify safe zone between mammillary bodies and infundibular recess. Create fenestration using blunt probe, balloon, or laser. Enlarge to 5-6mm.
steps.tips: Look for basilar artery through fenestration
steps.warnings: Avoid basilar artery - catastrophic hemorrhage if injured

steps.title: Verification & Closure
steps.description: Confirm patency by visualizing pulsatile CSF flow and underlying prepontine structures. Withdraw endoscope. Close wound in layers.
steps.tips: See the basilar artery and prepontine cistern through hole
steps.warnings: Inadequate fenestration will restenose

procedures.name: Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM) Resection
procedures.description: Microsurgical excision of cerebral arteriovenous malformation to eliminate hemorrhage risk.
procedures.indications: Ruptured AVM, Spetzler-Martin grade I-III, symptomatic unruptured AVM in young patients, failed embolization/radiosurgery
procedures.contraindications: High-grade AVM (IV-V) in eloquent cortex, deep AVMs with diffuse nidus, elderly with unruptured AVM

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Review DSA for feeding arteries, nidus location, draining veins. Calculate Spetzler-Martin grade. Consider preoperative embolization.
steps.tips: 3D reconstructions help understand angioarchitecture
steps.warnings: Identify deep feeders and en passage vessels

steps.title: Craniotomy
steps.description: Plan craniotomy to expose entire nidus plus surrounding normal brain. Use navigation for deep lesions.
steps.tips: Larger exposure allows better circumferential dissection
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to major draining veins before nidus isolation

steps.title: Identify Margins
steps.description: Use navigation, ultrasound, and visual inspection to define nidus margins. Identify all superficial feeding arteries and draining veins.
steps.tips: Arteries enter nidus, veins exit - critical distinction
steps.warnings: Never sacrifice draining vein until all feeders controlled

steps.title: Circumferential Dissection
steps.description: Dissect around nidus in gliotic plane. Coagulate and divide feeding arteries as encountered. Work circumferentially.
steps.tips: Stay in gliotic plane - easier dissection, less bleeding
steps.warnings: Entering nidus causes severe hemorrhage

steps.title: Deep Feeder Control
steps.description: As superficial feeders are divided, nidus will become softer. Identify and control deep/white matter feeders.
steps.tips: Progressive softening indicates good progress
steps.warnings: Deep feeders can retract if not properly coagulated

steps.title: Venous Disconnection
steps.description: Only after all arterial feeders are divided, coagulate and divide draining veins. Remove nidus en bloc.
steps.tips: Nidus should be completely deflated before vein division
steps.warnings: Premature vein sacrifice causes catastrophic swelling/hemorrhage

steps.title: Hemostasis & Verification
steps.description: Meticulous hemostasis of resection cavity. Perform intraoperative DSA to confirm complete resection. No residual AVM.
steps.tips: ICG angiography can supplement formal angiography
steps.warnings: Residual AVM has high rebleed risk - must be complete

procedures.name: Spinal Cord Tumor Resection
procedures.description: Microsurgical removal of intramedullary or intradural extramedullary spinal cord tumors.
procedures.indications: Progressive neurological deficit, radiographic tumor growth, symptomatic tumor, diagnostic uncertainty
procedures.contraindications: Diffuse infiltrative tumor, poor surgical candidate, stable asymptomatic lesion in elderly

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Review MRI for tumor location (intramedullary vs extramedullary), extent, and relationship to cord. Plan laminectomy levels.
steps.tips: Include one level above and below tumor
steps.warnings: Assess for syrinx which may extend beyond tumor

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Prone on Wilson frame or Jackson table. Apply neurophysiological monitoring: SSEPs, MEPs, EMG, D-waves.
steps.tips: Baseline monitoring before incision critical
steps.warnings: Significant MEP drop indicates cord injury

steps.title: Laminectomy/Laminoplasty
steps.description: Midline incision, subperiosteal dissection. Perform laminectomy or laminoplasty to expose dura over tumor extent.
steps.tips: Laminoplasty preserves stability in multi-level exposure
steps.warnings: Avoid dural injury during bone removal

steps.title: Dural Opening
steps.description: Open dura in midline. Identify tumor location. For extramedullary tumors, tumor visible immediately. For intramedullary, identify cord expansion.
steps.tips: Tack up dura to prevent epidural bleeding
steps.warnings: Avoid cord manipulation before adequate exposure

steps.title: Tumor Resection - Extramedullary
steps.description: For schwannoma/meningioma: identify tumor-cord plane, internally debulk, then dissect capsule from cord. Preserve nerve roots if possible.
steps.tips: Nerve root of origin often must be sacrificed for schwannoma
steps.warnings: Avoid cord retraction - use tumor manipulation instead

steps.title: Tumor Resection - Intramedullary
steps.description: Perform midline myelotomy. Develop plane between tumor and cord. Use ultrasonic aspirator for internal debulking. Dissect margins carefully.
steps.tips: Ependymomas have good plane, astrocytomas infiltrate
steps.warnings: MEP changes mandate pause - irrigate and wait

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Achieve hemostasis. Close dura watertight. Replace laminae if laminoplasty performed. Close fascia and skin in layers.
steps.tips: Watertight dural closure prevents CSF leak/pseudomeningocele
steps.warnings: Monitor neurological status closely postoperatively

procedures.name: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) Implantation
procedures.description: Stereotactic implantation of electrodes into deep brain nuclei for treatment of movement disorders.
procedures.indications: Parkinson disease with motor fluctuations, essential tremor refractory to medication, dystonia, OCD (humanitarian device exemption)
procedures.contraindications: Dementia, active psychiatric illness, unrealistic expectations, medical comorbidities precluding surgery, anticoagulation that cannot be stopped

steps.title: Target Selection & Planning
steps.description: Choose target based on indication: STN or GPi for Parkinson, VIM for tremor, GPi for dystonia. Plan trajectory avoiding vessels and ventricles.
steps.tips: Merge MRI with CT for frame-based coordinates
steps.warnings: Review trajectory for vessels on contrast MRI

steps.title: Frame Placement
steps.description: Apply stereotactic frame (Leksell, CRW) under local anesthesia. Ensure rigid fixation parallel to AC-PC plane.
steps.tips: Pin sites: frontal and occipital, above ear line
steps.warnings: Inadequate fixation causes targeting error

steps.title: CT/MRI Acquisition
steps.description: Obtain volumetric imaging with frame in place. Fuse images and calculate stereotactic coordinates. Verify trajectory.
steps.tips: Direct targeting on T2 MRI for STN visualization
steps.warnings: Confirm no shift from frame application

steps.title: Burr Hole & Dural Opening
steps.description: Frontal burr hole based on planned trajectory. Open dura with bipolar cautery. Apply fibrin glue to prevent CSF leak/pneumocephalus.
steps.tips: Entry point typically 2-3 cm lateral to midline
steps.warnings: Extensive CSF loss causes brain shift and targeting error

steps.title: Microelectrode Recording
steps.description: Advance microelectrode along planned trajectory. Record neuronal activity to identify target structure. Map boundaries.
steps.tips: Characteristic firing patterns identify each nucleus
steps.warnings: Multiple passes increase hemorrhage risk

steps.title: Test Stimulation
steps.description: Perform macrostimulation at target. Assess for tremor reduction, rigidity improvement, and side effects (paresthesias, diplopia, speech changes).
steps.tips: Therapeutic window = benefit threshold minus side effect threshold
steps.warnings: Low threshold side effects suggest electrode misplacement

steps.title: Permanent Electrode Implantation
steps.description: Replace microelectrode with permanent DBS lead. Secure with cap/burr hole ring. Confirm position with fluoroscopy.
steps.tips: Minimize lead manipulation to prevent displacement
steps.warnings: Document final coordinates for future reference

steps.title: IPG Implantation
steps.description: Tunnel extension wire to infraclavicular pocket. Connect to implantable pulse generator. Test impedances. Close in layers.
steps.tips: Can be same day or staged procedure
steps.warnings: Ensure adequate pocket size to prevent erosion

procedures.name: Carpal Tunnel Release
procedures.description: Surgical decompression of median nerve at the wrist by dividing the transverse carpal ligament.
procedures.indications: Failed conservative treatment, thenar atrophy, constant numbness, severe EMG findings, acute carpal tunnel syndrome
procedures.contraindications: Active infection, uncontrolled diabetes (relative), anticoagulation (relative)

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with arm extended on hand table. Apply tourniquet to upper arm. Prep and drape hand and forearm.
steps.tips: Exsanguinate arm before inflating tourniquet
steps.warnings: Note tourniquet time - limit to 2 hours

steps.title: Incision Planning
steps.description: Mark incision in line with radial border of ring finger, extending from wrist crease to mid-palm. Avoid crossing wrist crease perpendicularly.
steps.tips: Stay ulnar to thenar crease to avoid palmar cutaneous branch
steps.warnings: Incision too radial risks thenar branch injury

steps.title: Superficial Dissection
steps.description: Incise skin and palmar fascia. Identify palmaris longus tendon proximally. Expose proximal edge of transverse carpal ligament.
steps.tips: Protect superficial palmar arch distally
steps.warnings: Beware anatomical variants of median nerve

steps.title: Ligament Division
steps.description: Divide transverse carpal ligament under direct vision from distal to proximal. Use elevator deep to ligament to protect median nerve.
steps.tips: Complete release includes antebrachial fascia proximally
steps.warnings: Incomplete release is most common cause of failure

steps.title: Nerve Inspection
steps.description: Visualize median nerve after decompression. Note any compression, hourglass deformity, or neuroma. Perform neurolysis only if indicated.
steps.tips: Nerve should be mobile in canal after release
steps.warnings: Excessive neurolysis may cause scarring

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Release tourniquet, achieve hemostasis. Close skin only (palmar fascia left open). Apply soft dressing allowing finger motion.
steps.tips: Early finger motion reduces stiffness
steps.warnings: Avoid tight dressing that restricts circulation

procedures.name: Chiari Malformation Decompression
procedures.description: Posterior fossa decompression for Chiari I malformation with or without duraplasty.
procedures.indications: Symptomatic Chiari I (headaches, syrinx, myelopathy), progressive syringomyelia, sleep apnea related to Chiari
procedures.contraindications: Asymptomatic Chiari without syrinx, hydrocephalus (treat first), craniocervical instability (address first)

steps.title: Preoperative Evaluation
steps.description: Review MRI for tonsillar ectopia, syrinx, CSF flow study. Rule out hydrocephalus and craniocervical instability. Consider sleep study.
steps.tips: CSF flow study helps predict need for duraplasty
steps.warnings: Treat hydrocephalus before Chiari decompression

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Prone or sitting position with head in Mayfield. Flex neck to open posterior fossa. Prep from occiput to upper thoracic spine.
steps.tips: Sitting position reduces blood loss but has air embolism risk
steps.warnings: Avoid excessive neck flexion - can cause cord compression

steps.title: Exposure
steps.description: Midline incision from inion to C2/C3. Subperiosteal dissection of occiput and C1 posterior arch. Expose to foramen magnum edges.
steps.tips: Stay in midline to minimize blood loss
steps.warnings: Preserve C2 muscle attachments if not doing C2 laminectomy

steps.title: Bone Decompression
steps.description: Perform suboccipital craniectomy (3x3 cm minimum). Remove C1 posterior arch. Remove any constrictive fibrous band.
steps.tips: Extend laterally to sigmoid sinus if needed
steps.warnings: Avoid venous sinus injury at torcula

steps.title: Dural Assessment
steps.description: Assess dural tension and cerebellar tonsil position. If adequate CSF flow and minimal tonsil compression, may stop here (bone-only decompression).
steps.tips: Ultrasound can assess CSF flow before dural opening
steps.warnings: Some surgeons always perform duraplasty

steps.title: Duraplasty
steps.description: If proceeding with duraplasty: open dura in Y-shape. Shrink cerebellar tonsils with bipolar. Expand dura with pericranium, allograft, or synthetic patch.
steps.tips: Watertight closure reduces CSF leak
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to PICA along tonsil surface

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Achieve hemostasis. Watertight dural closure. Close muscle and fascia in layers. Consider drain if significant dead space.
steps.tips: Avoid Valsalva maneuvers postoperatively
steps.warnings: CSF leak/pseudomeningocele most common complication

procedures.name: Carotid Endarterectomy
procedures.description: Surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from the carotid artery to prevent stroke.
procedures.indications: Symptomatic carotid stenosis >50%, asymptomatic stenosis >70% in good surgical candidate, recurrent TIAs despite medical therapy
procedures.contraindications: Total occlusion, severe comorbidities, extensive distal disease, radiation-induced stenosis (relative)

steps.title: Preoperative Assessment
steps.description: Review imaging (CTA, MRA, or DSA) for stenosis severity, plaque morphology, and distal extent. Assess cardiac risk.
steps.tips: Identify high bifurcation or distal disease extent
steps.warnings: Recent large stroke increases perioperative risk

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with head turned away from operative side. Roll under shoulders. Mark incision along anterior SCM border.
steps.tips: Slight neck extension improves exposure
steps.warnings: Avoid excessive rotation in patients with contralateral stenosis

steps.title: Exposure
steps.description: Incision along anterior SCM. Divide platysma. Identify and protect facial vein, hypoglossal nerve, vagus nerve.
steps.tips: Facial vein marks carotid bifurcation level
steps.warnings: Hypoglossal nerve crosses above bifurcation - protect

steps.title: Carotid Dissection
steps.description: Expose common carotid, internal carotid beyond plaque, and external carotid. Minimal manipulation of bifurcation until ready to clamp.
steps.tips: Heparinize before clamping (80-100 U/kg)
steps.warnings: Avoid dislodging plaque fragments during dissection

steps.title: Shunt Decision
steps.description: Clamp carotid arteries. Assess need for shunt based on stump pressure, EEG changes, or routine use policy.
steps.tips: Stump pressure <40-50 mmHg suggests shunt need
steps.warnings: Shunt may cause intimal injury or air embolism

steps.title: Arteriotomy & Plaque Removal
steps.description: Longitudinal arteriotomy in common carotid extending into ICA. Develop endarterectomy plane. Remove plaque en bloc. Tack distal intimal edge.
steps.tips: Clean endpoint in ICA is critical
steps.warnings: Residual intimal flap causes postop occlusion

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Close arteriotomy primarily or with patch (vein or synthetic). Release clamps in sequence: ECA, CCA, then ICA. Confirm hemostasis.
steps.tips: Patch reduces restenosis risk
steps.warnings: Air/debris embolism during clamp release - flush technique important

steps.title: Postoperative Care
steps.description: Monitor BP closely (avoid hyper/hypotension). Neurological checks q1h. Watch for neck hematoma.
steps.tips: Hyperperfusion syndrome risk if severe preop stenosis
steps.warnings: Expanding hematoma requires immediate re-exploration

procedures.name: Epilepsy Surgery - Temporal Lobectomy
procedures.description: Anterior temporal lobectomy for medically refractory mesial temporal lobe epilepsy.
procedures.indications: Medically refractory temporal lobe epilepsy, concordant presurgical evaluation (MRI, EEG, PET), mesial temporal sclerosis
procedures.contraindications: Bilateral mesial temporal onset, memory impairment contralateral to planned resection, psychogenic nonepileptic events

steps.title: Presurgical Evaluation
steps.description: Confirm seizure focus with video-EEG, MRI (hippocampal sclerosis), PET, neuropsych testing, Wada test if needed.
steps.tips: Concordance of all studies predicts best outcome
steps.warnings: Discordant results may require invasive EEG monitoring

steps.title: Craniotomy
steps.description: Pterional or temporal craniotomy. Expose anterior and middle temporal gyri. Identify Sylvian fissure and temporal tip.
steps.tips: Bone flap should extend to middle fossa floor
steps.warnings: Protect vein of Labbé posteriorly

steps.title: Lateral Neocortical Resection
steps.description: Resect 3.5-4.5 cm of lateral temporal neocortex from temporal tip (dominant side 3.5 cm, non-dominant 4.5 cm).
steps.tips: Use ultrasonic aspirator for cortical resection
steps.warnings: Exceeding resection limits on dominant side risks language deficit

steps.title: Access Temporal Horn
steps.description: Enter temporal horn of lateral ventricle through white matter dissection. Identify choroid plexus and hippocampus.
steps.tips: Temporal horn entry confirms correct depth
steps.warnings: Avoid injury to optic radiations (Meyer loop)

steps.title: Amygdalohippocampectomy
steps.description: Resect amygdala, hippocampus, and parahippocampal gyrus. Subpial dissection along mesial structures. Preserve PCA and its branches.
steps.tips: Dissect along arachnoid plane over PCA
steps.warnings: PCA injury causes hemianopia or thalamic infarct

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Hemostasis in resection cavity. Replace bone flap. Close in layers. Postoperative MRI to confirm extent of resection.
steps.tips: Leave Surgicel in cavity for hemostasis
steps.warnings: Postoperative hematoma requires urgent re-exploration

procedures.name: Microvascular Decompression (MVD)
procedures.description: Posterior fossa surgery to relieve neurovascular compression causing trigeminal neuralgia or hemifacial spasm.
procedures.indications: Trigeminal neuralgia refractory to medication, hemifacial spasm, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, MRI showing vascular compression
procedures.contraindications: Multiple sclerosis-related TN (relative), elderly with significant comorbidities, no vascular contact on MRI

steps.title: Preoperative Imaging
steps.description: High-resolution MRI (CISS/FIESTA) to identify offending vessel and its relationship to nerve root entry zone.
steps.tips: SCA most common for TN, AICA for hemifacial spasm
steps.warnings: Absence of vascular contact on MRI reduces success rate

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Lateral decubitus or park bench position with affected side up. Head in Mayfield, flexed and rotated away. Monitor facial nerve, ABR.
steps.tips: Shoulder taping improves access
steps.warnings: Avoid air embolism - seal bone edges with wax

steps.title: Retrosigmoid Craniotomy
steps.description: Small (2.5-3 cm) craniotomy behind sigmoid sinus junction with transverse sinus. Expose dura over cerebellopontine angle.
steps.tips: Craniotomy should straddle transverse-sigmoid junction
steps.warnings: Injury to sigmoid sinus or emissary veins causes bleeding

steps.title: Dural Opening & CSF Drainage
steps.description: Open dura. Release CSF from cerebellomedullary cistern for brain relaxation. Minimal cerebellar retraction.
steps.tips: Patience with CSF drainage avoids retraction injury
steps.warnings: Aggressive retraction causes hearing loss

steps.title: Nerve Identification
steps.description: For TN: identify CN V at root entry zone in pons. For hemifacial spasm: identify CN VII at brainstem. Locate offending vessel.
steps.tips: Follow superior petrosal vein to trigeminal nerve
steps.warnings: Preserve all cranial nerves and perforating vessels

steps.title: Decompression
steps.description: Mobilize offending artery away from nerve. Place Teflon felt pledget between vessel and nerve root entry zone. Ensure no new compression.
steps.tips: Small pieces of Teflon, do not wrap nerve
steps.warnings: Excessive packing compresses nerve and worsens symptoms

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Hemostasis. Close dura watertight - consider dural sealant. Replace bone flap or cranioplasty. Close in layers.
steps.tips: Bone wax all mastoid air cells to prevent CSF leak
steps.warnings: CSF rhinorrhea can occur through opened air cells

procedures.name: External Ventricular Drain (EVD) Placement
procedures.description: Bedside or OR placement of catheter into lateral ventricle for CSF drainage and ICP monitoring.
procedures.indications: Acute hydrocephalus, ICP monitoring in TBI, intraventricular hemorrhage, CNS infection requiring intrathecal antibiotics
procedures.contraindications: Coagulopathy (correct first), scalp infection at insertion site, slit ventricles (relative)

steps.title: Preparation
steps.description: Gather EVD kit, sterile drapes, drill. Confirm correct side. Shave and prep insertion area. Administer prophylactic antibiotics.
steps.tips: Tunneled EVDs have lower infection rates
steps.warnings: Strict aseptic technique - EVD infection rate 5-15%

steps.title: Landmarks
steps.description: Mark Kocher point: 11 cm posterior to nasion (1 cm anterior to coronal suture), 3 cm lateral to midline (mid-pupillary line).
steps.tips: Non-dominant hemisphere preferred when possible
steps.warnings: Too lateral risks motor cortex, too medial risks sagittal sinus

steps.title: Incision & Burr Hole
steps.description: Make 3 cm incision. Create twist drill hole perpendicular to skull. Open dura with stylet or scalpel tip.
steps.tips: Plan tunnel exit site 3-5 cm from burr hole
steps.warnings: Ensure drill bit does not plunge

steps.title: Catheter Insertion
steps.description: Insert catheter perpendicular to skull surface, aiming at medial canthus of ipsilateral eye in coronal plane and tragus in sagittal plane. Advance 5-7 cm.
steps.tips: CSF flow usually obtained at 5-6 cm depth
steps.warnings: Multiple passes increase hemorrhage and infection risk

steps.title: Confirm Placement
steps.description: Confirm free-flowing CSF. Measure opening pressure. Collect CSF sample for lab analysis if indicated.
steps.tips: Normal ICP: 5-15 mmHg
steps.warnings: Bloody CSF may indicate parenchymal pass

steps.title: Tunneling & Securing
steps.description: Tunnel catheter subcutaneously to exit site 3-5 cm away. Secure with suture and dressing. Connect to drainage system.
steps.tips: Longer tunnel reduces infection risk
steps.warnings: Avoid kinking catheter during tunneling

steps.title: Set Drainage Level
steps.description: Set drainage level as ordered (typically 10-20 cm H2O above tragus). Verify CSF drainage. Obtain CT to confirm position.
steps.tips: Document drainage level and amount hourly
steps.warnings: Over-drainage can cause subdural hematoma or upward herniation

procedures.name: Posterior Cervical Laminectomy and Fusion
procedures.description: Posterior approach cervical decompression with lateral mass or pedicle screw fixation for multilevel stenosis.
procedures.indications: Multilevel cervical stenosis with myelopathy, cervical kyphosis with posterior compression, ossification of PLL, failed anterior approach
procedures.contraindications: Primarily anterior compression (relative), severe fixed kyphosis, active infection

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Prone with head in Mayfield. Maintain neutral cervical alignment. Slight flexion to open laminar spaces. Neuromonitoring: SSEPs, MEPs.
steps.tips: Reverse Trendelenburg reduces venous pressure
steps.warnings: Avoid hyperflexion in myelopathic patients - risk of cord injury

steps.title: Exposure
steps.description: Midline incision from occiput to upper thoracic spine as needed. Subperiosteal dissection to expose laminae, facets, and lateral masses.
steps.tips: Electrocautery on bone reduces bleeding from periosteum
steps.warnings: Do not violate facet capsules at levels not being fused

steps.title: Lateral Mass Screw Placement
steps.description: Identify lateral mass center. Use Magerl or An technique for screw trajectory. Drill, tap, and insert screws bilaterally.
steps.tips: Magerl: 25° lateral, 45° cephalad. An: 30° lateral, 15° cephalad
steps.warnings: Medial or inferior trajectory risks vertebral artery or nerve root

steps.title: Laminectomy
steps.description: Remove laminae from C3-C6/C7 as needed using Kerrison rongeurs and high-speed drill. Preserve C2 and C7 laminae if possible.
steps.tips: Trough technique: thin lamina bilaterally, then lift off
steps.warnings: Protect cord during lamina removal - use footplate attachment

steps.title: Foraminotomy
steps.description: Perform bilateral foraminotomies if foraminal stenosis present. Remove medial facet and uncovertebral osteophytes compressing nerve roots.
steps.tips: Remove no more than 50% of facet to maintain stability
steps.warnings: Venous plexus bleeding in foramen - use hemostatic agents

steps.title: Rod Placement
steps.description: Contour rods to match cervical lordosis. Insert and secure rods bilaterally. Apply compression or distraction as needed.
steps.tips: Restore or maintain cervical lordosis
steps.warnings: Loss of lordosis leads to post-laminectomy kyphosis

steps.title: Bone Grafting & Closure
steps.description: Decorticate lateral masses. Apply bone graft (local autograft + allograft). Close fascia, subcutaneous tissue, and skin over drain.
steps.tips: Meticulous fascial closure prevents wound complications
steps.warnings: Posterior cervical wound infections can be devastating

procedures.name: Awake Craniotomy with Brain Mapping
procedures.description: Craniotomy performed with patient awake for real-time cortical and subcortical mapping to maximize tumor resection while preserving neurological function.
procedures.indications: Tumors in or near eloquent cortex (motor, speech, language), low-grade gliomas in functional areas, recurrent tumors near eloquent regions
procedures.contraindications: Uncooperative patient, severe anxiety, language barrier, obesity with airway concerns, posterior fossa tumors

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Functional MRI and DTI tractography to map eloquent cortex and white matter tracts. Neuropsych baseline. Meet patient to establish rapport and rehearse tasks.
steps.tips: Patient education and trust are critical for success
steps.warnings: Screen for anxiety disorders - may need asleep-awake-asleep technique

steps.title: Anesthesia - Asleep Phase
steps.description: Scalp block with local anesthetic. Sedation with propofol/remifentanil for craniotomy phase (if asleep-awake-asleep). LMA or conscious sedation.
steps.tips: Generous scalp block reduces pain during awake phase
steps.warnings: Avoid respiratory depression during transition to awake

steps.title: Craniotomy
steps.description: Perform craniotomy to expose tumor and surrounding eloquent cortex. Ensure adequate exposure for mapping beyond tumor margins.
steps.tips: Larger exposure allows more mapping points
steps.warnings: Minimize brain manipulation before patient is awake

steps.title: Wake-Up Phase
steps.description: Discontinue sedation. Allow patient to fully awaken. Confirm orientation and ability to perform tasks (counting, naming, motor tasks).
steps.tips: Have familiar face (speech therapist) at bedside for reassurance
steps.warnings: Seizures during mapping - irrigate with cold saline, no retraction

steps.title: Cortical Mapping
steps.description: Apply bipolar stimulator (Ojemann) to cortical surface. Identify motor cortex (involuntary movement) and language areas (speech arrest, anomia, paraphasia).
steps.tips: Start at 2mA, increase by 1mA. Mark positive sites with numbered tickets
steps.warnings: If seizure occurs: cold irrigation, raise stimulation threshold

steps.title: Tumor Resection
steps.description: Resect tumor while continuously testing patient. Maintain 1 cm margin from positive mapping sites. Use subcortical stimulation near white matter tracts.
steps.tips: Subcortical stimulation at 3-5mA indicates proximity to tract
steps.warnings: New deficit during resection - stop, irrigate, reassess

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Hemostasis. May re-sedate patient for closure phase. Close dura, replace bone, close in layers.
steps.tips: Final neurological exam before closing
steps.warnings: Document all mapping sites and functional outcomes

procedures.name: Spinal Epidural Abscess Drainage
procedures.description: Emergency surgical decompression and drainage of spinal epidural abscess to prevent or reverse neurological deficit.
procedures.indications: Neurological deficit, progressive weakness, failure of antibiotic therapy, large abscess with cord compression
procedures.contraindications: Pan-spinal involvement (medical management), complete paralysis >48-72 hours (relative), prohibitive surgical risk

steps.title: Preoperative Assessment
steps.description: MRI with gadolinium to delineate abscess extent. Blood cultures, inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR, WBC). Identify organism if possible.
steps.tips: Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus
steps.warnings: This is a surgical emergency - do not delay for extensive workup

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Prone on Jackson table. Ensure neuromonitoring if available. Prep widely to cover entire abscess extent.
steps.tips: Mark levels with fluoroscopy before incision
steps.warnings: Septic patient may be hemodynamically unstable

steps.title: Exposure
steps.description: Midline incision over affected levels. Subperiosteal dissection to expose laminae. Extend one level above and below abscess.
steps.tips: Culture any purulent material encountered during approach
steps.warnings: Avoid contaminating unaffected tissue planes

steps.title: Laminectomy
steps.description: Perform laminectomy over abscess extent. Open ligamentum flavum carefully. Purulent material will be encountered in epidural space.
steps.tips: Wide laminectomy ensures complete drainage
steps.warnings: Inflamed dura is fragile - avoid durotomy

steps.title: Abscess Drainage
steps.description: Evacuate purulent material with suction. Send cultures (aerobic, anaerobic, TB, fungal). Irrigate copiously with saline.
steps.tips: Explore laterally into foramina for loculated collections
steps.warnings: Do not irrigate under pressure - may spread infection

steps.title: Inspection & Debridement
steps.description: Inspect dura for granulation tissue. If discitis present, debride disc space. Assess for vertebral body osteomyelitis.
steps.tips: Biopsy bone if osteomyelitis suspected
steps.warnings: Extensive bone debridement may require subsequent fusion

steps.title: Closure & Drain
steps.description: Place drain in epidural space. Close fascia and skin. Continue IV antibiotics for 6-8 weeks. Monitor CRP for treatment response.
steps.tips: Loose fascial closure if significant dead space
steps.warnings: Recurrence may require re-exploration

procedures.name: Endoscopic Endonasal Skull Base Surgery
procedures.description: Extended endoscopic endonasal approach for midline skull base lesions beyond the sella.
procedures.indications: Craniopharyngioma, tuberculum sellae meningioma, clival chordoma, anterior skull base CSF leak, esthesioneuroblastoma
procedures.contraindications: Significant lateral extension beyond carotid arteries, vascular encasement, nasal/sinus infection

steps.title: Preoperative Planning
steps.description: Detailed CT/MRI review. CT angiography for carotid artery course. Plan surgical corridor: transtuberculum, transplanum, transclival, or transcribriform.
steps.tips: Thin-cut CT for bony anatomy, MRI for soft tissue relationships
steps.warnings: Identify carotid artery dehiscence or aberrant course

steps.title: Nasal Phase
steps.description: Bilateral nasal approach. Harvest nasoseptal flap (Hadad-Bassagasteguy) for reconstruction. Wide bilateral sphenoidotomy.
steps.tips: Preserve septal branch of sphenopalatine artery for flap viability
steps.warnings: Flap harvest before tumor removal - cannot go back

steps.title: Bony Opening
steps.description: Remove bone over surgical corridor using drill and Kerrison rongeurs. Transplanum, tuberculum, or clivus based on pathology. Expose dura widely.
steps.tips: Egg-shell bone then remove with curettes for control
steps.warnings: Identify and preserve optic canals and carotid prominences

steps.title: Dural Opening
steps.description: Open dura sharply. Identify arachnoid plane. CSF will be encountered - maintain clear field with two-surgeon technique.
steps.tips: Bimanual technique with surgeon and assistant essential
steps.warnings: Vascular injury risk during dural opening near carotids

steps.title: Tumor Resection
steps.description: Extracapsular dissection when possible. Debulk internally for large tumors. Careful dissection from optic nerves, pituitary stalk, hypothalamus.
steps.tips: Angled endoscopes (30°, 45°) provide visualization around corners
steps.warnings: Hypothalamic injury causes devastating endocrine/behavioral deficits

steps.title: Skull Base Reconstruction
steps.description: Multilayer closure: inlay fascial graft, onlay nasoseptal flap, tissue sealant. Buttress with Foley balloon in sphenoid.
steps.tips: Nasoseptal flap is workhorse for large defects
steps.warnings: Poor reconstruction leads to CSF leak and meningitis

steps.title: Postoperative Care
steps.description: Bed rest with HOB elevated. Lumbar drain for 3-5 days if high-flow leak. Nasal precautions. Endocrine monitoring.
steps.tips: Avoid straining, nose blowing, sneezing with mouth closed
steps.warnings: Delayed CSF leak can occur 1-2 weeks postoperatively

procedures.name: Ulnar Nerve Transposition
procedures.description: Surgical decompression and anterior transposition of the ulnar nerve at the elbow for cubital tunnel syndrome.
procedures.indications: Failed conservative treatment, progressive weakness/atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles, severe EMG findings, recurrent subluxation
procedures.contraindications: Active infection, severe medical comorbidities, mild symptoms responding to conservative care

steps.title: Patient Positioning
steps.description: Supine with arm on arm board, elbow flexed 90°. Apply tourniquet. Mark course of ulnar nerve over medial epicondyle.
steps.tips: Map nerve with ultrasound preoperatively if revision case
steps.warnings: Protect medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve

steps.title: Incision
steps.description: 10-12 cm curvilinear incision centered on medial epicondyle, curving anteriorly proximal and distal.
steps.tips: Stay posterior to medial epicondyle then curve anterior
steps.warnings: Avoid crossing elbow crease perpendicularly - scar contracture

steps.title: Nerve Identification
steps.description: Identify ulnar nerve proximal to cubital tunnel in intermuscular septum. Trace distally through cubital tunnel and into FCU fascia.
steps.tips: Identify nerve proximally where anatomy is normal
steps.warnings: Nerve may be subluxed or adherent to scar in revision cases

steps.title: Decompression
steps.description: Release all compression points: arcade of Struthers, medial intermuscular septum, Osborne ligament (cubital tunnel roof), FCU fascia.
steps.tips: Complete release extends 8-10 cm proximal and distal to epicondyle
steps.warnings: Incomplete release is common cause of failure

steps.title: Transposition
steps.description: Mobilize nerve with its vascular pedicle. Excise medial intermuscular septum. Create subcutaneous or submuscular pocket. Transpose nerve anteriorly.
steps.tips: Submuscular gives most protection but requires muscle healing
steps.warnings: Avoid kinking at proximal or distal ends of transposition

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Create fascial sling to prevent nerve from returning posteriorly. Close in layers. Soft dressing with elbow at 90°. Begin gentle ROM in 1-2 weeks.
steps.tips: Sling from flexor-pronator fascia prevents re-subluxation
steps.warnings: Prolonged immobilization causes elbow stiffness

procedures.name: Stereotactic Brain Biopsy
procedures.description: Minimally invasive stereotactic or frameless neuronavigation-guided biopsy of intracranial lesion for histological diagnosis.
procedures.indications: Deep-seated lesion not amenable to resection, multifocal lesions, diagnostic uncertainty, CNS lymphoma suspected, eloquent area lesion
procedures.contraindications: Coagulopathy, vascular lesion (AVM, aneurysm), lesion in highly vascular area, accessible lesion better treated with resection

steps.title: Target Planning
steps.description: Select biopsy target on MRI. Choose enhancing portion avoiding necrotic center. Plan trajectory avoiding vessels, ventricles, and eloquent cortex.
steps.tips: Target enhancing rim for highest diagnostic yield
steps.warnings: Avoid choroid plexus, ependymal surfaces, and major vessels

steps.title: Frame Placement or Registration
steps.description: Apply stereotactic frame and obtain CT for co-registration, OR use frameless neuronavigation with fiducial registration.
steps.tips: Frame-based is gold standard for accuracy (<2mm error)
steps.warnings: Verify registration accuracy before proceeding

steps.title: Incision & Burr Hole
steps.description: Small incision at planned entry point. Create burr hole. Open dura and coagulate pia.
steps.tips: Twist drill sufficient for most biopsies
steps.warnings: Hemostasis at cortical entry point prevents tract hemorrhage

steps.title: Biopsy Acquisition
steps.description: Advance biopsy needle to target depth using stereotactic guidance. Obtain multiple samples from different areas of lesion.
steps.tips: 4-6 samples from different sites increases diagnostic yield
steps.warnings: Minimize number of trajectories to reduce hemorrhage risk

steps.title: Frozen Section
steps.description: Send specimen for intraoperative frozen section to confirm diagnostic tissue obtained. Pathologist confirms adequate tissue.
steps.tips: Continue sampling if frozen shows only necrosis/gliosis
steps.warnings: Frozen section may not give final diagnosis - wait for permanent

steps.title: Closure
steps.description: Remove needle. Achieve hemostasis with irrigation and Surgicel. Bone wax burr hole. Close skin. CT scan postoperatively.
steps.tips: Observe in ICU for 24 hours
steps.warnings: Hemorrhage rate 1-5% - postop CT mandatory
